entry.title: Integration & Extensibility - Bulgaria EUR Transition for S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud Live Customers
entry.content:
This is only relevant for Partners and Live Customers who are required to transit Production system data with EUR adoption in Bulgaria. How To Guide Collection - Bulgaria EUR Transition for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Live Customers

In the 2nd session offered by ASC Cloud ERP Expertise Services,  two main topics are covered , Integration and Extensibility.

  • Recording on August 13, 2025 Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Integration & Extensibility)
  • Presentation on August 13, 2025 Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Integration & Extensibility)
  • Accelerator
    • Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Integration & Extensibility) Extensibility Generic Guidelines
    • Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Integration & Extensibility) S4HC Extensibility Template
    • Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Integration & Extensibility) Integration Generic Guidelines
    • Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Integration & Extensibility) S4HC_Integration Template

Key Discussion Pointsâ€Œ

â€Œ1. Integration

â€ŒOverview:â€Œ Focused on system integration impacts due to Bulgaria's EUR transition, including company code, currency, and cost center changes.

  • â€ŒAccelerators Provided:â€Œ
    • â€ŒInterface Assessment Guide:â€Œ Lists affected interfaces (e.g., SAP-to-SAP, third-party) based on company code/currency dependencies.
    • â€ŒStep-by-Step Change Guide:â€Œ Covers middleware adjustments (filters, value mappings), prerequisites before making any changes, master data replication, and testing.
  • â€ŒKey SAP Integrations:â€Œ
    • â€ŒSuccessFactors:â€Œ Requires new legal entity creation and cost center reassignment.
    • â€ŒFieldglass/ Concur/ Ariba:â€Œ Updates to WBS structures and cost center mappings.

â€Œ2. Extensibility

  • â€ŒScope:â€Œ Covers key user (UI fields, custom logic, Custom CDS, Output Forms) and developer (ADT tools, BTP apps) extensibility.
  • â€ŒChecklist for Custom Objects:â€Œ
    • â€ŒCustom Fields/Logic/Custom CDS/Custom Business Objects:â€Œ Verify hardcoded company codes/currencies.
    • Output Management Master/Content Forms : Verify Rule Determination for Master Forms and Output Parameter Determination for Content forms, check logic implemented directly in the custom Forms
    • â€ŒForms/Workflows:â€Œ Update determination rules for new company codes.
  • â€ŒTools:â€Œ
    • â€ŒExtensibility Inventory App:â€Œ Export custom objects for analysis.
    • â€ŒADT (Eclipse):â€Œ Manually scan developer extensibility code for hardcoded values.

2. Live Questions & Answers

â€ŒTopic Areaâ€Œ

â€ŒQuestionâ€Œ

â€ŒAnswerâ€Œ

â€ŒExtensibility Toolsâ€Œ

Is there a tool to mass-check custom logic for hardcoded company codes/currencies?

No automated scanner exists. For developer extensibility, use Eclipse ADT to manually search code. For key user extensibility, export objects via the Extensibility Inventory App and review individually.

â€ŒExtensibility Inventoryâ€Œ

Should we export the extensibility inventory from production?

Yes, filter exported objects in production to focus on active customizations. Non-promoted items in development can be ignored.

â€ŒSession Coverageâ€Œ

Are similar sessions available for S/4HANA On-Premise?

No confirmed sessions. On-Premise guidance differs (e.g., secondary company code approach). Refer to SAP Notes for details.

â€ŒTroubleshootingâ€Œ

How to troubleshoot integration/extensibility issues post-changes?

Use integration traces (payload analysis) and debug custom logic in ADT. Enable custom logic tracing for detailed error tracking.

3. Call-to-Action

entry.title: How to find CDS views in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
entry.content:
TLDR

With 3-tier S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition you can now connect your ABAP Developer Tools (ADT, in Eclipse) directly to the system.  You can browse development objects including CDS views. Creating an ABAP Repository Tree allows you to browse by component and release status, to find released views to use in your extensions

Remind me, what is S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition?

S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition (or Public CE) is SAP's SaaS ERP. Formerly known as S/4HANA Cloud, and as S/4HANA Public Cloud, this flavour of S/4 emphasises a tight fit to standard business processes.  The solution is hosted and managed by SAP. Only clean-core extensions are possible and upgrades happen according to a published schedule

Why does S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition matter?

Whilst the largest customers tend to draw most of the limelight in the SAP world, there are only so many of them.  As you widen your gaze to include progressively smaller and smaller customers their number increases more than proportionately.  In other words there are a lot more companies with 10,000 employees that there are with 100,000 employees.  There are a heck of a lot more companies with 1000 employees that there are with 10,000. This means that the total market is huge, even if each individual subscription is smaller

Ceteris paribus, these smaller customers are more likely to go for Public CE, because it can be more cost effective for them.  Indeed the inability to perform 'dirty' extensions & enhancements, and the inability to stay on a outdated release can be seen as advantages of Public CE.  SAP's vision is that over time more and more customers will switch to Public CE, some after 'cleaning up' their legacy enhancements.  They hope that, over time, larger and larger customers will sign up

How can we extend S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition?

Whilst a fit to standard processes is the goal, Public CE can be extended and enhanced if needed.  There might be a small variation to fit a competitive advantage that that particular customer has, their 'special sauce' if you like.  Historically these extensions could be categorised as

  1. On-stack key-user extensions

  2. Side-by-side developer-built extensions on BTP

To support the latter type we expose data via the SAP-standard published APIs, by creating custom CDS views or by creating custom business objects with a back-end service enabled. Events can also trigger extensions on BTP

Why are released views precious?

To expose standard data that isn't part of a published API we must (if 2-tier) use the custom CDS view option. We can only use released views as sources, and only a fraction of views are released.  Why is that?  Well, releasing a view is a big deal for SAP because it represents a promise to keep that view available and up to date.  If this wasn't the case our extensions could break every upgrade cycle, as standard views or fields on standard views were removed.  This would limit the viability of Public CE altogether 

Hence finding released views with the right data is an important part of extension design.  Happily, that task is getting easier, with the increased prevalence of the 3-tier landscape with Public CE

Why are 3 tiers better than 2?

When my first customer went live with Public CE in 2019 all setups had Test and Prod environments only.  Having a background at big on-prem customers, with their 5 or 6 tier landscapes (e.g. Sandbox / Dev / Test / Pre-Prod / Prod / Training) I found this pretty scary!

Now all new Public CE customers get 3 tiers ( Dev / Test / Prod ) and existing customers are being migrated.  The Dev environment has 2 tenants, for development and for customizing. Under the hood, these represent client 80 and client 100. This facilitates the introduction of a new enhancement technique.  Using the embedded ABAP Cloud environment we can use RAP (the ABAP Restful Programming Model) to build OData services. This gives far greater flexibility that we get building custom CDS views in a Fiori app (as a 'key-user')

This on-stack extensibility was known for a while as Embedded Steampunk

Of course, finding released CDS views is still important, because ABAP cloud will only allow us to use released CDS views as data sources. So what's the best way to find them?

What's the best way to find released CDS views in a 3-tier Public CE landscape?

Once you've connected your ABAP Development Tools to your S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition system (development tenant/client 80) you can browse all of the development objects.  This is something that just wasn't possible before, because we were limited to what we could see in various Fiori apps

If you try to browse all of the CDS views, you will likely hit an issue as there are just too many to be rendered.  I recommend instead building your own ABAP Repository Tree (via File->New).

On the first screen (of the repo tree wizard) select Core Data Services

On the next screen, in the Selected Tree Levels, remove package from level 3, and replace it with Application Component.  Then select drag the API State level over to level 4.

Click Finish. Now, in the tree, you can open Core Data Services, Data Definitions and then the component of your choice.  The released views are found under USE_IN_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT. You can open the individual view to see the definition.

You can confirm that the view is released by considering the API State tab in the properties, on the bottom right of your Eclipse screen. C1 Use System Internally is the key part.  If it is Released you should be able to use this view in a custom CDS view or in RAP development

Because you are connected to your dev system you can see the release status of every view which is available on your current release

What do you think?

Are you an expert on extensions already?  Or are you surprised at how much scope there is for extension on S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition?  Extensions certainly got a little easier, now that we can see every view available. Let me know in the comments what you think, and if you have any tips for finding views

I would love to find a good way to find CDS views which use a given table as a source (directly or indirectly).  This can be done in the View Browser app, but we won't see all of the views. Perhaps in future SAP could support using the where-used feature in ADT

entry.title: First Experiences GenAI-driven extensibility assistant for Custom Fields and Custom Logic app
entry.content:
These are my first experiences with the extensibility assistant

Use within Custom Fields:


You can call the extensibility assistant in the Custom Fields app start screen, and in the details screen of a single custom field.

Calling the extensibility assistant in the start screen:

Example Prompt :Create a Z field in the Journal Entry Item Level , Field Name : Reference1 and Field Description : Reference 1_HD , Data Type : Char/Text Field Length : 20 and Enable it for the RAP BO I_JOURNALENTRYTP

In the initial screen of the Custom Fields app on the button bar at the top right of the custom field list, you'll find a open assistant button. 

Enter the prompt it will preselect Business context

 After selecting the right context accept the proposal from SAP it will create the field and enable to edit for detail screen 

Calling the extensibility assistant in the details screen:

  • On the button bar at the bottom of the screen, you'll find the diamond button.

  • if you want to ask about a custom field displayed on the details screen, you can refer to it using expressions like â€œthis fieldâ€. A common use case is seeking assistance to expose the field through an OData service, UI, CDS view, or SOAP API.

  • Once selected Press save and publish manually . As you see from the below the field is automatically extended in the SOAP API section based on the prompt .

 

Use within Custom Logic:

  • Start the extensibility assistant in the Custom Logic app by clicking the Open Assistant button on the implementations table toolbar

 

  •  The extensibility assistant will show a list of BAdIs that fit your request or a message if no BAdIs were found. 

Select and create implementation . This will only help to find right BADIs not generation of the coding in the BADI ğŸ™‚

entry.title: Sales Document BAdI Overview in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Sales Document BAdI Overview

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, customers' business processes can be fundamentally covered by SAP best practice solutions. To meet various customer business requirements, extensibility is essential. In terms of extensibility, Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) are critical as they allow customers to implement custom logic to influence SAP standard business processes.

In SAP ECC or SAP PCE/OP, there are User-exits and VOFM Routines available that customer could update standard business object in business processings. As these techniques are not supported in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) become the most prevalent approach to influence SAP standard business processes. 

Up to SAP S/4HANA CE2508, there are following Cloud BAdIs defined in sales order processing. These Cloud BAdIs are called in well defined process sequence. For instance, the BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD is always processed before the BAdI "SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE". 

 

This blog explains the definition of Cloud BAdIs in sales order processing. I hope this blog can help you better understand sales order BAdIs and enable you to utilize them effectively in your business. 

Benefit of Sales Document BAdIs

The following benefits illustrate how sales document BAdIs can fulfill customer requirements:

  • Sales document Cloud BAdIs provide capabilities that enable customers to implement custom logic to influence the sales order process, regardless of the channel through which the sales order is processed.
  • Sales document Cloud BAdIs ensure that the custom logic is processed within the same LUW (Logic Unit of Work).
  • Since Cloud BAdIs are always triggered automatically, they reduce the complexity for business users and increase efficiency.

Definition of Sales Document BAdIs

Most sales document BAdIs are defined on following business contexts:

  • Sales: Sales Document (Header)
  • Sales: Sales Document Item (Item)

There are other business contexts used in sales BAdIs which work for some special sales business processes, such as:

  • Sales: Listing/Exclusion
  • Sales: Sales Order Request
  • Sales: Sales Scheduling Agreement Delivery Schedule
  • Sales: Text Determination

Since all sales document BAdIs are documented in SAP help, I will not explain them again in this blog. However, I will categorize those BAdIs into the following groups.

Pre-processing BAdIs

There is no official term for "Pre-processing BAdI" in SAP. Here, I would like to refer to all BAdIs that are triggered before the core processing of the sales document as "Pre-processing BAdIs," including the following:

BAdI NameDescriptionBusiness ContextPurpose/Usage
SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_BILCopying Requirements for Sales Documents (from Billing Documents)Sales: Sales DocumentYou can use this BAdI to provide routines for copying requirement from billing document to sales document
SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLSCopying Requirements for Sales Documents (from Sales Documents)Sales: Sales DocumentYou can use this BAdI to provide routines for copying requirement from sales document to sales document
SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEADData Transfer for Sales Document HeadersSales: Sales DocumentYou can implement this BAdI to influence the data transfer of copy control

Transactional BAdIs

The transactional BAdI is processed in transactional manner during business object processing. It can be processed multiple times based on business object operation. For example, the sales order modify BAdI (SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD) is triggered as soon as sales order header is processed. 

Most sales document transactional BAdIs can influence sales document processes, for example, you can implement transactional BAdIs to modify sales document custom fields or certain standard fields. 

Since the sales document data is changed frequently by user interaction, the import parameters of the transactional BAdIs may not be stable. The field values set by custom logic could also be overwritten by standard logic or other custom logic due to dependencies. 

Below table lists transactional BAdIs in sales document process.

SD_SLS_CHECK_ITEMCheck of Item Data in Sales DocumentsSales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement custom logic to check sales document item and raise messages
SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEADModification of Header Custom Fields in Sales DocumentsSales: Sales DocumentIt is possible to modify custom fields on sales document header level via this BAdI

SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD_BUSINESSModification of Business Data in Sales Document HeadersSales: Sales DocumentIt is possible to modify some standard fields on sales document header level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM_BUSINESSModification of Business Data in Sales Document ItemsSales: Sales Document ItemIt is possible to modify some standard fields on sales document item level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD_TAXModification of Tax Data in Sales Document HeadersSales: Sales DocumentIt is possible to modify tax-relevant fields on sales document header level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM_TAXModification of Tax Data in Sales Document ItemsSales: Sales Document ItemIt is possible to modify tax-relevant fields on sales document item level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM_REQDATE
Modification of Requested Delivery Date for Sales Document ItemsSales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement this BAdI to modify requested delivery date on item level
SD_SLS_CHECK_DELETE_ITEMCheck of Sales Document Items Before DeletionSales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement this BAdI to disallow deletion of sales document items

Final Phase BAdIs

The final-phase BAdI differs from the transactional BAdI because the final-phase BAdI is processed during the document save. Normally, the final-phase BAdI is called only once during the save process, and the import parameters are relatively more stable.

The user may not see the impact of the final-phase BAdI immediately during their interactions. In many cases, the user only sees the result after the business object is saved. The end user has limited control over the custom logic implemented in the final-phase BAdI.

In customer's end-to-end business, the final-phase BAdIs are quite important to fulfill various business requirements, especially for automated processes like API channel, integration channel, etc. 

Here are most used final-phase BAdIs in sales document process.

SD_SLS_FINALIZEModification of Sales Document in Finalize Phase before Save

Sales: Sales Document 

Sales: Sales Document Item

SD_APM_SET_APPROVAL_REASONApproval Request Reasons for Sales DocumentsSales: Sales Document You can implement custom logic to control whether a sales document should trigger the workflow approval

Post-processing BAdIs 

Post-processing BAdIs are triggered after the sales document is processed, and normally do not prevent the sales document from being saved. 

Following BAdIs are categorized as post-processing BAdIs in sales document process.

APOC_ADD_EMAIL_RECIPIENTSBAdI: Addition of Email RecipientsOutput Request Item You can implement this BAdI to add email recipients in sales document output items

Determination BAdIs 

There are some determination BAdIs triggered in sales document processing but not defined in sales document business context, e.g. listing/exclusion determination, text determination, pricing, etc. 

Following Cloud BAdIs are relevant to sales document processing.

BAdI NameDescriptionBusiness ContextPurpose/Usage
SD_LSTG_EXCLSN_RQMT_DOCRequirements in Listing/Exclusion for Sales DocumentsSales: Listing/Exclusion You can implement this BAdI to define requirement for listing/exclusion in sales documents
SD_LSTG_EXCLSN_RQMT_DOC_ITEMRequirements in Listing/Exclusion for Sales Document ItemsSales: Listing/Exclusion :  You can implement this BAdI to define requirement for listing/exclusion in sales document items
SD_TEXTS_COPY_REQUIREMENTCopying Requirement in Text DeterminationSales: Text Determination You can implement this BAdI to define requirement for text determination in SD documents
SD_TEXTS_DATA_TRANSFERData Transfer in Text DeterminationSales: Text Determination You can implement this BAdI to change the source text that transferred in sales documents
PRICING_DOCUMENT_REQUIREMENTDefine Requirement in Pricing for DocumentPricing You can implement this BAdI to control pricing requirement in sales documents
PRCG_DOCUMENT_ITEM_REQUIREMENT
Define Requirement in Pricing for Document ItemPricing You can implement this BAdI to control pricing requirement in sales document items

Things Behind the Scenes 

We often receive questions about sales document BAdIs from customers and partners in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Some of those questions are generic and applicable to many customers and partners, so it makes sense to share the details of those points here. 

Why are User-Exits not available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud?

Answer: according to clean core extensibility guidance (see SAP note 3578329), user-exits are kind of modification and not supported in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Only the Cloud BAdIs and the released APIs are recommended in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. 

Why are only some fields from the sales document available as import parameters in the BAdI?

Answer: there are following reasons to decide what fields shall be exposed in Cloud BAdI as import parameter:

  • Field mapping is costly in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. We only expose most useful fields into Cloud BAdIs as parameters for performance consideration.
  • Only the Global Field Name (GFN) is allowed to be exposed in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Not all sales document fields have GFN defined. 

Why are many sales document standard fields not modifiable via Cloud BAdI?

Answer: it is always challenging to update sales document standard fields via custom logic because of dependencies. There are many standard logic processes that determine standard fields based on other fields during sales document processing. Inappropriate custom logic to update standard fields could lead to the following issues:

  • The standard field set by custom logic could be overwritten by standard logic 
  • Using Cloud BAdI to update standard fields might jeopardize standard sales document processes
  • Business object data could become inconsistent due to inappropriate custom logic determination

Therefore, only some sales document standard fields are possible to be modified by Cloud BAdIs. The product team is working hard to bring more changeable standard fields into Cloud BAdIs. 

Summary

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides many Cloud BAdIs that allow customers and partners to influence standard sales document processes for various business purposes. A better understanding of Cloud BAdIs can help customers and partners decide how to best utilize them to fulfill business requirements.

I will also introduce some blog posts that explain real use cases for specific sales document Cloud BAdIs. Please stay tuned for updates.

Functional areas in SAP S/4HANA Cloud are organizational units used for classifying expenses by their nature rather than by operational or geographical divisions. They serve as a key component in cost-of-sales accounting and enable businesses to prepare segmental financial statements for compliance and decision-making purposes. The derivation of functional areas is determined based on the sequence as explained here. In this short blog post, I would like to cover a practical example of how the functional area derivation works using a custom logic substitution rule, which is the last sequence step of the derivation logic. In this demo example, the use case is that the derivation should take place only for the company code 0800, and the default functional area will be substituted by a target functional area which is entered in a custom field of a professional services customer project. The prerequisite is creating and enabling the custom field YY1_Functional_Area_WP_cpd  in the business context "Work Package".

Step 1:

Create a custom logic implementation for the Extension Point FIN_CODING_BLOCK_SUBSTITUTION

Add the following code: in this example, if the Company Code 0800 is used, the custom logic will substitute the default functional area with the functional area entered by the user into the custom field.

* Note: please always copy the values from input to output first before

* any substitutions, otherwise, the initial values from the output will

* be used for substitutions!!

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING codingblockitem TO codingblockitemout.

 

DATA lv_project_target_fa type STRING.

*Only valid for customer projects, as the custom field is created in this context

IF codingblockitem-companycode = '0800'.

    SELECT YY1_Functional_Area_WP_cpd FROM I_WORKPACKAGE

    INTO _project_target_fa

    WHERE WORKPACKAGE = @codingblockitem-wbselementexternalid.

    ENDSELECT.

    "If the custom field value if empty, no substitution

    If  lv_project_target_fa IS INITIAL.

        EXIT.

    ELSE.

        codingblockitemout-functionalarea = lv_project_target_fa.

        substitutiondone = abap_true.

    ENDIF.

ENDIF.

Step 2:

Next, create the substitution rule for this custom logic to be executed. In the â€œManage Substitution/Validation Rules â€“ Journal Entriesâ€ app, create a new rule for the business context Coding Block as follows:

 

The precondition determines in which cases the substitution rule will be triggered â€“ in our demo use case, we want the rule to trigger only when the source functional area is equal to 'YB25'. The substitution rule itself simply maps the target field value to the value of the source field functional area (which will be set to a new value during the runtime of the custom logic). So essentially, if the customer project custom field has a target functional area 'YB24' maintained, the default functional area YB25 will be replaced by 'YB24'.

entry.title: Cloud BAdI to Update Sales Order in Finalize Phase
entry.content:
Cloud BAdI to Update Sales Order in Finalize Phase

As I explained in blog Sales Document BAdI Overview, there are limited sales document fields can be modified via custom logic in BAdI due to various reasons. On the other hand, we are receiving customer requirements to update sales document standard fields via custom logic to control standard business processes. It is a journey to enhance extensibility in sales document processes to better fulfill business requirements. 

Here I am happy to announce a new Cloud BAdI will be introduced in CE2508 which allows customers to modify custom fields and certain standard fields in sales document finalize phase before save. Please find detail information in https://api.sap.com/badi/SD_SLS_FINALIZE.

Why New BAdI?

As there are already many Cloud BAdIs available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, I am often asked why a new BAdI should be introduced rather than reusing existing ones. Here are some considerations we received from customers and partners regarding our existing Cloud BAdIs:

  • In transactional BAdIs like SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD or SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM, customer can only access partial sales document information. For example, customers cannot access schedule line data from BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD. If a customer wants to use schedule line data to update custom field at the sales document header level, this cannot be achieved by implementing custom logic in BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD. 
  • The BAdI import parameter is not stable and reliable in transactional BAdIs like SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD or SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM, as these BAdIs are called multiple times during sales document processing. 
  • In automatic channels that do not involve user interaction, transactional BAdIs are not the best option for influencing the sales document process. Instead, the BAdIs that are processed only once during document saving are more suitable for handling such use cases. For example, the SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE BAdI is only called during the save process. 
  • The BAdI import parameter is more stable in finalize phase BAdIs like SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE, and all sales document entities are accessible via this BAdI. However, it is not possible to update any sales document data in this BAdI as it was was only defined to check the sales document before saving. 

Definition of New Cloud BAdI

To address the demands from customers and partners, a new BAdI, SD_SLS_FINALIZE, has been introduced to update the sales document data during the finalize phase before save. This new Cloud BAdI has following aspects:

  • The import parameters are more reliable because this BAdI is processed during sales document save phase
  • All sales document entities are accessible through this BAdI 
  • Custom fields on both sales document header and item can be modified via this BAdI
  • Certain standard fields can be modified via this BAdI, such as the rejection reason code at the line item level

Let's take a closer look at the details of new Cloud BAdI SD_SLS_FINALIZE. 

BAdI Parameters

Following import parameters are defined in this BAdI so that customer can access those entities:

  • sales document header
  • sales document header partners
  • sales document items
  • sales document item partners
  • sales document schedule lines

Following changing parameters are defined in this BAdI so that customer can modify sales document data:

  • custom fields on sales document header level
  • custom fields on sales document item level
  • rejection reason code on sales document item
  • control fields to indicate what field is modified 

Business Example 

I'd like to use a business example to explain how this BAdI fulfills a business requirement. 

Supplier company XYZ sells products to different customers via portal. When customers place orders in the supplier portal, the OData API is called to create sales orders. The order creation process in supplier company XYZ is fully automatic. Only in exceptional cases sales experts will manually operate the sales order through the sales order UI. 

Due to fluctuations in the prices of raw materials, company XYZ generally does not accept customer orders with long-term delivery requests. To ensure financial risk is under control, system shall automatically reject customer orders requested to be delivered later than 1 month.  

Solution via Extensibility

The sales document finalize BAdI is the best option to handle this use case, as the finalize BAdI SD_SLS_FINALIZE works across all sales document processing channels. It is ideally suited for handling the automatic order creation scenario from supplier company XYZ. 

Define Reject Reason Code

Go to SSCUI 102494 to define a new rejection reason code for long-term delivery request. 

This reject reason code will be used in the BAdI implementation when customer requested delivery date is in 30 days away. 

BAdI Implementation

Open the app "Custom Logic" and create a BAdI implementation for BAdI SD_SLS_FINALIZE.

Implement following ABAP code and then publish the BAdI implementation. 

* Set the rejection reason to sales order item when customer requested delivery date is
* 30 days away
  if salesdocument-salesdocumenttype = 'TA' and salesdocument-salesorganization = '1010'.
    "check is customer requested delivery date is more than 30 days from today
    if salesdocument-requesteddeliverydate - salesdocument-creationdate > 30.
      loop at salesdocumentitems_change assigning field-symbol(<ls_item_change>).
        <ls_item_change>-salesdocumentrjcnreason = 'Z1'.
        <ls_item_change>-control-salesdocumentrjcnreason = abap_true.
      endloop.
    endif.
  endif.

Test Sales Order via UI

Create a sales order in Fiori application and set the requested delivery date within 30 days. 

Add the item and save the order. System shows nothing is rejected.

Create a new sales order and set the requested delivery date in November. 

Add items and save the sales order. 

After the sales order is saved, both sales order items are rejected with the rejection reason code 'Z1' which was set in BAdI implementation logic.

Go to status view and system indicates all items are rejected.

Test Order Creation via OData API

Call sales order A2X OData API to create a sales order. In the OData API payload, the requested delivery date is set on September 10th which is within 30 days period. 

The sales order 23311 is created via OData call. Go to system to check if line item is rejected in this sales order. 

Then create a new sales order via OData API call, and set the requested delivery to November 10th which is out of 30 days period. 

Open the sales order 23313 and check if line item is rejected automatically. 

Test Order Simulation via OData API

Order simulation via API call is also important for customer's business scenario. Since the sales document finalize BAdI is called in all sales document processing channels, using custom logic to reject line item in order simulation is also possible. 

Call sales order A2X OData simulation API to simulate the order creation and set the requested delivery date to November 10th which is out of 30 days period.

Check the OData simulation response in the right panel, the sales document item rejection fields are updated based on BAdI logic. 

Moving Forward

The sales document finalize BAdI will be helpful in fulfilling various business use cases to influence sales document processes. Currently, this BAdI is only available for sales orders and sales orders without charge. 

In the future, based on customer requirements, this BAdI will be enhanced to support more sales document types and allow the modification of additional standard fields. Please feel free to submit your requirement through the Customer Influence Portal to help us prioritize our product roadmap.

entry.title: How to use key-user in-app Custom Logic extensibility to change eDocument currency in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Introduction

Some countries (like Colombia) might required to have reports sent to fiscal authority on their local currency even if the transaction was executed in a different currency and is registered on the system in a foreign currency. On  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition this requirement might be delivered in some localizations via extensibility as a localization as a Self-service to be implemented during implementation project.

Below example, shows how a sale in USD would be reported without the extensibility (left) and with extensibility solution (right):

Solution through Extensibility 

Based on a demand for Colombia invoice eDocument, we have developed the KBA 3648968.

On the KBA, we instruct how to find extension points (BAdIs) to change information in eDocument generated via eDocument Cockpit or Manage Electronic Documents apps. We also highlight that for each localization, it should be consulted the SAP Help Portal documentation for that localization to check which extension points are available and which should be used.

We also provide a proof-of-concept sample code that shows how the change for a XML file created for an eDocument for Colombia can be changed. Note that each localization and eDocument likely will have different extension points and limitation as well as each implementation might have its own requirements that will result on complete different code.

So each implementation should develop its own code and the KBA code is only an example and do not cover all scenarios nor is a final solution to be implemented.

entry.title: How SAPâ€™s ABAP Cloud Partner Reference App Simplifies Multi-Tenant Side-by-Side Extensions on BTP
entry.content:
The SAP BTP ABAP environment continues to unlock powerful opportunities for partners and developers seeking to extend and integrate with SAP Cloud ERP - particularly SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, by enabling SaaS extension development, leveraging existing ABAP expertise, and delivering benefits such as harmonized user experience, built-in product standard compliance, and simplified lifecycle management and operations out of the box. To further support this process, SAP offers the open-source ABAP Partner Reference Application as a best-practice resource.

The ABAP Partner Reference Application on SAP-Samples Git repository demonstrates how to design, build, and operate multi-tenant side-by-side applications using ABAP Cloud practices while following SAPâ€™s recommended development approaches. The ABAP Partner Reference Application provides developers and technical architects with standard patterns, modular code, and documented guidance for building robust, multi-tenant ABAP applications on SAP BTP, fully integrated with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It guides partners on designing, deploying, and extending ABAP solutions. It provides a blueprint for building scalable, multi-tenant apps that extend and integrate with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

What is the ABAP Partner Reference Application?

The ABAP Partner Reference Application (APRA) is a sample implementation that provides practical examples, such as the Music Festival Manager. It shows partners how to:

  • Build extensions on SAP BTP ABAP Cloud.
  • Integrate seamlessly with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Handle critical multi-tenant aspects such as tenant provisioning, onboarding, and isolation.
  • Follow SAPâ€™s ABAP Cloud and Restful ABAP Programming Model (RAP) guidelines.

In short, itâ€™s a real-world blueprint for partners who need a reference starting point.

Key Capabilities Highlighted

  • Multi-tenancy design: APRA showcases how to build applications that serve multiple tenants securely while keeping data isolated.
  • Tenant lifecycle management: Includes practical examples of provisioning and onboarding processes.
  • Integration patterns: Demonstrates how ABAP applications can consume SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs side by side, extending core business logic without modification.
  • Best practices in ABAP Cloud: Clean-core extensions, RAP-based services, and modular design patterns are applied throughout

Why It Matters for Partners

For partners building SAP-certified solutions, alignment with ABAP Cloud principles is no longer optional. APRA offers more than just example code: it provides implementation guidance to ensure solutions are cloud-ready, scalable, and compliant. By studying and adapting the repository, partners save time, reduce uncertainty, and can fast-track their certification and deployment processes.

  • The repository demonstrates and aligns with SAP clean-core architecture and RAP best practices, enabling maintainable, upgrade-safe solutions. Along with modularization, helping partners build solutions that are scalable, maintainable, and compliant with SAPâ€™s cloud-first best practices.
  • It provides real-world samples for rapid development of side-by-side extensions in the SAP BTP ABAP environment.
  • It demonstrates end-to-end flows: business object modelling, onboarding and provisioning, secure multi-tenancy, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition API integration. It includes example business objects, tenant-specific onboarding logic, and detailed sample integrations with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs, serving as ready-to-adapt templates for real-world enterprise scenarios.
  • Each stepâ€”from tenant lifecycle management to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition functionality using side-by-side applicationsâ€”is implemented with guidance notes and sample ABAP artifacts, making cloud development approachable for teams at any skill level.
  • Multi-Tenancy Patterns: Learn how to isolate data and processes by tenant, automate provisioning, and secure user access using SAP BTP role collections and dedicated onboarding flows.
  • Integration Points: Discover how to consume core APIs, events, and data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition while preserving ERP clean core, using recommended SAP BTP services for authentication, navigation, and extensibility.
  • RAP and ABAP Cloud Usage: Access sample RAP service definitions and back-end logic that illustrate SAPâ€™s latest cloud-based application paradigms, making it straightforward to adopt modern development models.

 Getting Started / How to Use the Repository

The repository is publicly available on GitHub and welcomes exploration. Developers can:

  • Import the Music Festival Manager application from your abapGit repository into your ABAP environment in ADT, browse the artifacts, and review the README for instructions on deployment and configuration to start with ready-to-run examples or tutorials.
  • Follow the incremental development guides in the main branch to build up your own ABAP partner app using the same best practices. Follow examples for multi-tenant design, onboarding, and integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Analyze business object definitions, RAP service implementations, and onboarding/integration logic to adapt for your own solution. Use the sample reference application as templates for partner apps, adapting the RAP artifacts and onboarding logic for your business scenario and leverage the documented guidance to use APRA as a starting template for your own solutions.

Inside the Repository: Packages and Artifacts

  • The repository is organized to guide developers through building a core ABAP application, then evolving it into a multi-tenant solution.
  • Artifacts are grouped by application logic (business objects), onboarding flows, integration APIs, and service definitions that illustrate SAPâ€™s recommended RAP approach.
  • The samples Music Festival Manager and Poetry Slam Manager demonstrate business object modeling, UI integration, and tenant isolation in real-world use cases.

 How the Repository Accelerates Partner Solutions

  • Partners can reuse packages, study onboarding approaches, and adapt integration modules directly for their own certified offeringsâ€”streamlining time to market and improving solution quality.
  • Step-by-step documentation, real code, and sample data flows empower developers to master multi-tenant patterns and extend SAP Cloud systems with confidence.
  • The repository acts as a knowledge base and starter kit for enterprise ABAP cloud projects, bridging theory and practical implementation for SAPâ€™s partner ecosystem.

By exploring this repository, developers and architects gain hands-on experience with the foundations of multi-tenant architecture, SAP BTP-managed security, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integrationâ€”directly addressing the needs of modern cloud-native SAP applications.

For partners, the repository turns cloud-native theory into practice. Get hands on with SAP BTP ABAP Cloud, accelerate certified solution development, and leverage proven patterns for multi-tenant extensionsâ€”all with guided help from SAPâ€™s own reference implementation.

entry.title: Enhanced Mapping of Advanced VariantConfiguration Characteristic Values to ProductionOrder Operation
entry.content:
Introduction

With the SAP Cloud ERP for Public Cloud 2502.4 release, a valuable new feature has been introduced, 'Enhanced Mapping of Advanced Variant Configuration Characteristic Values to Production Orders'. This enhancement allows you to map variant configuration characteristic values directly to custom fields within production routing operations. These custom fields can then be used as parameters in Work Centre formulas to dynamically calculate activities such as machine processing time, labour, and setup costs.

In this blog post, we'll explore how this feature can be applied in a real-world scenario to improve cost accuracy and operational efficiency in a manufacturing process.

Business Scenario

Imagine an automobile manufacturing company where the sit fitment time and cost vary depending on the number of seats to be installed in a custom-built caravan. In the custom-built caravan production process, the sit fitment time is calculated based on the number of seats selected by the customer during order configuration. In this case, the sit fitment time is expressed as machine time, calculated using a custom formula in the Work Centre.

Letâ€™s say the time factor is 1 for assembling 5 seats, which serves as the base configuration. We then maintain time factors of 3 for 6 seats and 5 for 7 seats to represent the proportionally higher effort and machine time required as the seat count increases, due to added installation work, alignment, and quality checks.

The table below illustrates this:

Seat Count (Z_SEAT_COUNT)

Time Factor (Z_SAFT)

Explanation

5

1

Base time unit

6

3

3Ã— time of 5-seat fitment

7

5

5Ã— time of 5-seat fitment

Consider the characteristic Z_SEAT_COUNT captures the number of seats selected. The system uses a dependency procedure (e.g., SEAT_ASSEMBLY) to calculate the machine time factor (Z_SAFT), which is then used to determine the overall operation time in routing.

This feature is especially valuable for industries that manufacture products with dynamic or customizable designsâ€”such as automotive, furniture, modular kitchens, pool tile manufacturing, or industrial machineryâ€”where production time and cost vary significantly based on configuration-specific attributes.

In the following section, weâ€™ll walk through how this use case can be implemented using the new feature in SAP Cloud ERP for Public Cloud.

Prerequisites

Before implementing this feature, ensure the following prerequisites are met:

  1. Activate the Feature
    Enable the feature "Map Object Dependency Value to Operation" (FTGL_PPH_MD_MAPOBJDPNVALS_2) via the Activate Features configuration activity in your system.

  1. Create a Custom Field
    Define a custom field under the business context Manufacturing: Bill of Operations Operation. This field will be used in the Work Centre formula to calculate activities like machine, setup or labour time and cost.
    For detailed steps on how to create a custom field and incorporate it into a Work Centre formula, refer to the link below:
    ğŸ‘‰https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/step-by-step-guide-to-setting-up-custom-fields-in-work-center-formula/ba-p/14123514
  2. Create a Super Routing with Object Dependency
    Set up a Super Routing for the configurable material and assign an Object Dependency of type 'Procedure' to the relevant operation.
    For guidance on how to create a routing for configurable materials, refer to the documentation below:
    ğŸ‘‰https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f369b2eff700401494ba6e7c9a573288/d5ed07180f7a40189b043c8156157919.html?version=2502.500

Step-by-Step Execution:

1) Create and Verify Custom Field
Ensure that a custom field is created in the business context Manufacturing: Bill of Operations Operation. This field should be visible at the operation level in the routing.
In this example, weâ€™ve created a custom field called Seat Assembly Time Factor (YY1_SEAT_ASSEMBLY_TIME_PPO) to represent the offset value used for time and cost calculation.

2) Define Work Centre Formula
Create a Work Centre formula (e.g., Z_TIME) that uses a parameter (e.g., Z_SATF) linked to the custom field created above. This formula will be used to dynamically calculate activity times based on the selected configuration

3) Assign Formula to Work Centre Activities
Assign the custom formula (Z_TIME) to the relevant activity types (e.g., Setup, Machine, or Labour) in the Work Centre (SEATASMB) responsible for the seat assembly operation.    

4) Create Characteristic and Map to Custom Field
Define a variant configuration characteristic (e.g., Z_SATF) and map it to the custom field YY1_SEAT_ASSEMBLY_TIME_PPO. This enables the system to pass characteristic values to the routing operation dynamically.

5) Create Super Routing and Assign Procedure
Set up a Super Routing for the configurable material (e.g., a car model), and assign an Object Dependency of type â€˜Procedureâ€™ to the relevant operation (e.g., Seat Assembly).
In this example, the Seat Assembly Time Factor (Z_SATF) is determined based on the selected number of seats. The procedure is defined as below,

WorkCentre SEATASMB assigned to the operation 0025 â€“ Assemble Seat Units

Object dependency of type Procedure

Dependency Editor

6) Create Sales Order and Test Configuration
Once all the above steps are complete, create a Sales Order for the configurable material. On the Variant Configuration screen, select the desired number of seats.
Then, review the machine cost and overall calculated activity costs â€” they should adjust dynamically based on the selected characteristic value (i.e., the number of seats).

a) Select number of seats as â€˜5â€™ in the variant configuration screen

Cost of Goods Sold and Seat assembly machine processing cost for 5-seater.

b) Select number of seats as â€˜6â€™ in the variant configuration screen

Cost of Goods Sold and Seat assembly machine processing cost for 6-seater.

c) Select number of seats as â€˜7â€™ in the variant configuration screen

Cost of Goods Sold and Seat assembly machine processing cost for 5-seater.

Conclusion

The â€œEnhanced Mapping of Advanced Variant Configuration Characteristic Values to Production Ordersâ€ feature in SAP Cloud ERP for Public Cloud 2502.4 offers greater flexibility and accuracy in manufacturing configurable materials. By mapping configuration characteristics to custom fields in production operations and using them in Work Centre formulas, manufacturers can calculate activity times and costs dynamically based on real-time inputs. In the seat assembly example, processing time and cost adjust based on the number of seats selected, improving cost transparency and operational efficiency. This is especially valuable in make-to-order and engineer-to-order scenarios, where production effort varies with each configuration.

By leveraging it, businesses can better align operational planning with customer-specific configurationsâ€”driving both efficiency and customer satisfaction.

Happy Learning!!

entry.title: Taking Control of Clean Core: When to Use Project Kernseife in addition to Standard SAP Tools
entry.content:
TL;DR

Measuring SAP Clean Core involves a choice:

  • As a RISE with SAP customer, you can benefit from the out-of-the-box standard approach with SAP Cloud ALM. The RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard provides you with a high-level standardized view with minimal effort.
  • Or you can choose an open-source, highly flexible, and customizable approach with Project Kernseife. You get custom classification to create actionable insights, but it requires ownership and additional effort.

This article will help you decide which path is right for your team's Clean Core journey.

How the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard measures Clean Core

SAP's answer on how to measure clean core is based on two standard tools: The ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) (and its newly released checks as from SAP Note 3565942) and the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard in SAP Cloud ALM.

The process begins with the ATC, which analyzes your custom code against a well-defined set of rules. The key to this analysis is the classification of your custom extensions based on the official release status of the standard SAP objects they utilize. This release information is transparently published by SAP in the Cloudification Repository (Viewer).

As described in more detail in the Clean Core Extensibility Whitepaper (see chapter 3.3), the ATC assigns your extension a level based on the most critical SAP object it utilizes:

  • Level A - For extensions using only stable, released objects, ensuring maximum upgrade security.
  • Level B - For extensions whose most critical dependency is a classic API like a BAPI or classic technical frameworks.
  • Level C - For extensions touching any unreleased, internal SAP objects.
  • Level D - For extensions using objects that are explicitly not recommended.

The results of this structured analysis can then be uploaded to SAP Cloud ALM, populating the Clean Core Extensibility KPIs in the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard. Recently, the dashboard was enhanced with a display of the Clean Core  Levels. This gives organizations a high-level, standardized view of their extensibility landscape, which is perfect for assessing their current situation and tracking progress. For the near future (Q1/2026) it is moreover planned to offer a deep dive dashboard that provides further details about the results.

What is "Project Kernseife"?

Project Kernseife is an open-source custom ATC Check for ABAP systems that enables you to flexibly score the usage of SAP objects in your system, e.g. to score the technical debt regarding clean core based on a custom, adjustable classification. More details on the parts and approach can be found in the blog "Project Kernseife - improving the measurement of Clean Core in ABAP".

Why Project Kernseife and its custom classification can be a Game-Changer for Clean Core Governance

Advantage 1: Fine-Tune SAP's Rules & Reduce "False Positives"

While SAP delivers thousands of released and classic APIs, it might still be not the perfect fit for your individual project and scope. Kernseife allows you to customly classify objects as "acceptable for your project", dramatically reducing noise and the need for mass ATC exemptions. Let's look into two different scenarios, to show you the benefits of custom classification:

Example 1: Stricter governance for direct table read

Within the standard classification, a direct read with a SELECT from any SAP table is considered as "Level C", which leads to warnings in ABAP Test Cockpit. In your project, you want to enforce the usage of ABAP cloud, you maybe have (see next point) identified many successor objects (custom and standard) and want to push developers to the successors objects (e.g., famous I_Product instead of MARA) by showing these as an error.
Remark: In standard ATC, you can adjust the priority of a check message in general (for example "Reading from DDIC database tables or DDIC table views is not recommended (successor available)", but not based on specific SAP objects you refer to.

Example 2: Need for usage of "internal object"

Now let's imagine you are working in a "clean core" project, but you need to extend processes around the Outbound Delivery Orders in EWM. After talking to experts, finding blog posts and even an "official" SAP Note, you identified the right interface: /SCWM/IF_API_WHR_OUTBOUND. Unfortunately, this is not yet listed as released or classic API. This would result in "warnings" in ATC and a classification as Level C ("Internal Objects" are used), although you did the best you can do. With Kernseife, you can now mark this SAP object as "recommended", which results in only "information" messages in ATC and leads to a "Level B" assessment of the custom code object / extension.

Based on these two examples, you can see: this is the power of a custom classification. You can overrule the SAP standard, be it because of timing (as you need the announced adjustments from the blog IMMEDIATELY) or scope (because SAP might not generally classify everything that you identify as "acceptable for your project" as "Classic API").

The possibility to "accept" usage of certain SAP objects will increase your governance quality, as your exemption approvers will not be flooded with hundreds of "false" exemption requests for objects that you generally accept in your project.

Advantage 2: Define and Enforce Custom Successors

While SAP is already delivering hundreds of the most important successor classifications (famous MARA -> I_Product), there might still be potential to guide your developers more precisely. Project Kernseife allows you to maintain a successor object in your classification, that will also be visible in the result of your ATC check - this makes it actionable for your developer!

 

Example 1: "Improve" Standard Successors

There are some more tables in the system, that have no successor mentioned officially, but where you can find (released!) CDS views as an alternative. To not flood you with details here, I simply refer to another blog based on the idea of @AndreasGraeber. But also for Function Modules or classes , there might be clear successors (e.g. not all READ_<table> might be having the successor information. There might be a lot of areas, where you want to decide in your project "don't use this, but use that!"

Example 2: Enforce and centralize Wrappers / custom successors

What happens if you create a wrapper for a standard SAP object, but your colleagues are not aware of it? They might re-create the same wrapper. With the possibility to also add Custom Objects (e.g. Z_WRAPPER_ABC) as a successor, you can also push your developers to harmonize the usage of wrappers.

Advantage 3: Enhance Dashboards for Measurement and Governance with consistent transparency

In several projects, we have already seen custom dashboards to track the current state of clean core. With the combination of the level concept and the "Technical Debt Score", you can assess systems and drill down into packages or even single objects.

Project Kernseife offers you direct access (e.g. with CDS-View ZKNSF_I_SCORING) to the data from ATC check runs to build these dashboards. You can use the Kernseife BTP Application to analyze your score - or create your own dashboard, for example with SAP Analytics Cloud, reflecting your custom rules to assign custom objects to business units (e.g. ZBR* is always Brasil).

The scoring is based on your configuration in the Kernseife classification, which allows you to own the definition of your clean core levels and deviate from SAP's standard definition - by this you own the definition of your clean core levels! To stick with the examples above, the usage of /SCWM/IF_API_WHR_OUTBOUND will impact your score in a limited way.

Advantage 4: Prioritize Your Cleanup Efforts with a "Potential Score"

After an analysis, you often face a daunting list of findings. The biggest challenge isnâ€™t just identifying the issues, but knowing where to start the cleanup. This is where Kernseife's scoring mechanism becomes a powerful prioritization engine by providing two key metrics for each finding: a Score and a Potential Score.

  • The Score reflects the technical debt of the object as it exists today, based on your custom rules.
  • The Potential Score shows what the score would be if the developer refactored the code to use the defined successor.

Let's use our familiar example:

  • Your classification assigns a high "Technical Debt" Score of 10 for a direct SELECT on table MARA.
  • The officially released successor, I_Product, has a "clean" score of 0. Therefore, the finding's Potential Score is 0.

This creates a clear, quantifiable "improvement gap." An object with a Score of 10 and a Potential Score of 0 is a high-impact cleanup opportunity. In contrast, a finding with a Score of 2 and no defined successor (meaning its Potential Score is also 2) is a lower priority for immediate refactoring.

By sorting your findings based on the largest gap between the Score and Potential Score, you can instantly identify the "low-hanging fruits" and the refactoring tasks with the biggest impact. Let's be clear, this is just one piece of information, and maybe you shouldn't have any custom code in this area based on a process analysis, but I still believe it is important to have data to drive your decisions - and Project Kernseife offers you data for the technical insights.

Making the Right Choice: A Balanced Look at Both Approaches

Key Reasons to Adopt Project Kernseife

The main reason to use a Project Kernseife is typically the power of the custom classification (as the last chapter pointed out). You can adjust the classification of SAP objects based on your project reality and support your clean core journey with tailored data.

In addition, there might be a temporary, tactical benefit: As of today, Kernseife's dashboards can fill a gap until SAP's "Extensibility Deep Dive" dashboard is generally available. 

Important Considerations: When the Standard Approach is a Better Fit

At the same time, I want to be very clear: Project Kernseife is not needed in every company and project.

  • 1. The Need for Standard Alignment: If your primary goal is to align perfectly with SAP's out-of-the-box reporting and dashboards without deviation, the standard approach is more appropriate.
  • 2. The Responsibility of Power: Custom classification is powerful, but it requires ownership. Someone must define, document, and maintain these custom rules. This is an ongoing responsibility (and effort!), which you can spare yourself when you go with the standard solution, i.e. RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard.
  • 3. Implementation and Maintenance Overhead: While straightforward for experienced teams, implementing and maintaining any non-standard solution requires effort that must be planned for. It is ironically against the clean core imperative of leveraging "standard"!
  • 4. Unified Classification enables comparibility: Standardized classification leads to a comparability between different systems (e.g., you compare your central finance system with a peer system regarding the clean core level share), as the classification is the same for all systems.

Conclusion: Do you need to Take Control of Your Clean Core Strategy?

Project Kernseife is not for everyone. It is for organizations that find the standard clean core measurement too rigid and are ready to invest the effort to build a more nuanced, context-aware governance model. If you have the capacity and the architectural vision, it can transform your clean core initiative from a technical cleanup exercise into a strategic management of your system's extensibility.

Interested in more? Check out Project Kernseife: our open-source project where you can join the community, contribute, and support us with a GitHub star in the repository!
